p: The WHO discussion on the operation of the influenza network began in 1951 at a conference held in Copenhagen, and in 1952, the WHO Global Influenza Surveillance Network was launched [ 10]. In May 2011, the Pandemic Influenza Preparedness Framework was adopted, which involved sharing of influenza virus characteristics and other benefits of vaccines, and its name was changed to Global Influenza Surveillance and Response System (GISRS). The GISRS consists of 144 national influenza centers, 6 WHO collaborating centers (CCs), 4 essential regulatory laboratories, and 13 H5 reference laboratories (H5RefLabs) as of 2019 [ 11].
